awd_titl_txt: Conference: 2023 Molecular Mechanisms in Evolutions GRC and GRS: Genetic and Phenotypic Evolution at the Organismal, Cellular and Molecular Levels
awd_abstract_narration:
Molecular biology and evolution are the two fundamental unifying principles of life on earth. It is only through the combination of knowledge from these two disciplines that we can (i) unravel how the molecular components of organisms allowed them to survive their past environments, (ii) understand the challenges imposed by present day ongoing evolution occurring in immune cells, cancer tissues or microbial populations, including pathogens, (iii) predict the future responses of organisms to climate changes and other human-driven current selective pressures. The 2023 Gordon Conference on Molecular Mechanisms in Evolution will assemble international experts in molecular, medical, and evolutionary biology to present the latest findings and diverse perspectives on the molecular basis of evolutionary change. This conference will provide an engaging atmosphere for open and creative discussions aimed at stimulating collaboration among the participants. Short talks and posters will provide young scientists and their ideas access to the opinions and suggestions of the more experienced scientists who are invited speakers and chairs. 

The conference program will cover a wide range of topics including: the evolution of proteins and RNAs, the evolution of mutation and recombination rates, non-genetic variation and inheritance, metabolic evolution, the making of complex traits. The principal goal of this GRC is to encourage and nurture a community of researchers, spanning several formal disciplines, with a shared interest in the molecular basis of evolutionary change across biological scales. Evolutionary scientists include ecologists, geneticists, evolutionary, cellular, and molecular biologists, as well as physicists, and applied mathematicians. With such a wide range of disciplines, it is important to provide an opportunity to experts in these diverse disciplines to appreciate the important discoveries and new technologies from across the breadth of evolutionary science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The 2023 edition of conference on "Molecular Mechanisms in Evolution" proved to be a resounding success, attracting a diverse and enthusiastic audience from around the world. With registration numbers exceeding expectations and attendance hitting maximum capacity, the event demonstrated its significant appeal to the scientific community. 

Intellectual Merit:

A key exciting outcome of the conference was the initiation of numerous new collaborations. Although it is early to detail all the partnerships formed, the event built on the success of previous years, where significant collaborations such as those between Gresham and Ram, as well as Jacobsen and Hartl, were established. These past examples set a promising precedent for the new connections made this year, suggesting a fruitful future for collaborative research in molecular evolution.
The conference featured a series of cutting-edge talks that captivated the audience. Presentations covered a wide range of topics, showcasing the latest advancements and innovative research in molecular mechanisms and their role in evolution. These talks not only provided valuable insights but also sparked lively discussions and debates among attendees, further enhancing the conference's interactive nature. 

Broader Impacts:

A notable feature of the conference was its inclusive environment, with an almost equal representation of women and men among speakers and attendees and a large fraction of early-career researchers (ECRs) among the speakers. This emphasis on diversity not only enriched the discussions but also highlighted the progressive nature of the event. The engagement with ECRs was particularly impressive, fostering a collaborative atmosphere that is essential for the advancement of science.
In addition to the engaging talks, the poster sessions were extremely well attended. These sessions offered an excellent platform for researchers, especially ECRs, to present their work and receive feedback from more experienced scientists. The vibrant exchanges that took place during these sessions underscored the collaborative spirit of the event and provided a fertile ground for new ideas and potential partnerships.
Summary: 

Overall, the "Molecular Mechanisms in Evolution" conference was marked by its high registration and attendance numbers, robust representation from across the globe, significant involvement of women and ECRs, and a strong emphasis on collaboration. The success of this event, including the full engagement of attendees and the formation of new research partnerships, promises to drive forward the field with fresh perspectives and innovative approaches.
